head.title: New and Notable In the East 50's

hedline.hl1: New and Notable In the East 50's

abstract.p: Excerpts from previously published reviews of restaurants in Manhattan's East 50's (Good Eating column) (M)

block.p: BELLINI ++ (212) 308-0830; 208 East 52nd Street, between Second and Third Avenues; $$; smoking at the bar and in smoking section; all major credit cards.

The airy walls and tile floors are attractive here. And more important, the service is particularly thoughtful. Appetizers include baked littleneck clams with seasoned bread crumbs; lightly pan-fried mozzarella with an anchovy caper sauce; Atlantic grilled calamari with diced zucchini, eggplant and tomato; and escarole, sweet sausage and white bean soup. Main dishes include breast of chicken dipped in egg batter, over a bed of spinach; veal scaloppine topped with eggplant, prosciutto and mozzarella in a tomato sauce; and monkfish sauteed in light tomato sauce, garlic, fresh herbs and shiitake mushrooms. (Diner's Journal: 5/29/98)
BELLINI ++ (212) 308-0830; 208 East 52nd Street, between Second and Third Avenues; $$; smoking at the bar and in smoking section; all major credit cards.

The airy walls and tile floors are attractive here. And more important, the service is particularly thoughtful. Appetizers include baked littleneck clams with seasoned bread crumbs; lightly pan-fried mozzarella with an anchovy caper sauce; Atlantic grilled calamari with diced zucchini, eggplant and tomato; and escarole, sweet sausage and white bean soup. Main dishes include breast of chicken dipped in egg batter, over a bed of spinach; veal scaloppine topped with eggplant, prosciutto and mozzarella in a tomato sauce; and monkfish sauteed in light tomato sauce, garlic, fresh herbs and shiitake mushrooms. (Diner's Journal: 5/29/98)
BRASSERIE ** [Rating: Two Star] (212) 751-4840; 100 East 53rd Street, at Lexington Avenue; $$$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

Patrons of the old Brasserie enter, and their jaws drop. You still descend a staircase to reach the famous downstairs dining room, but there's a new glamour to the place, which has been given a very expensive face lift. Appetizers include crab cake; tuna tartare; escargots petit gris; and foie gras au torchon. Entrees include duck cassoulet; Chilean sea bass with lemon grass and lime; roasted chicken, thyme jus and truffled mashed potatoes; and rigatoni with cherry tomatoes, garlic, broccoli rape and aged parmesan. Desserts include chocolate beignets with caramel ice cream; chocolate mousse and peanut ganache with chocolate ice cream; and mixed berries with grapefruit sorbet. (Review: 3/15/00)
NICHOLSON ++ (212) 355-6769; 323 East 58th Street, between First and Second Avenues; $$$; smoking at the bar and lounge; all major credit cards.

With its parquet floors, painted wall tiles and antique settees, Nicholson feels like a room in a remote corner of a sprawling chateau. There are three tasting menus of four, six and eight courses. The four-course menu features oysters in a shallot jelly; white asparagus and caviar napoleon; civet of cod with pistachio and a light bearnaise sauce, or loin of lamb with a yellow squash flan and a nero sauce; and almond sorbet. The six-course menu features coq of lobster with assorted caviar; endive salad with Asian pears, apple chips, mustard and chive dressing; potato tart with house smoked salmon and caviar; squab salad dressed with white truffle oil; navarin of John Dory with a froth of fennel, or braised rabbit with daikon lasagne; and honey ice cream. The eight-course menu features sea scallops with a bright citrus topping; sweet and sour cherry tomato salad with basil vinaigrette; lamb carpaccio with a mint and basil glaze; scarlet croustillant of shrimp with a white truffle cream reduction; Belgian endive sauteed with cured goose liver; salmon-trout served with a chicory sabayon; fillet of pork with braised oxtail, galette potatoes, soubrises, onion and watercress puree or lobster souveroff en cocotte with chestnuts; and crystallized rose petals with a rose water granite. (Diner's Journal: 5/5/00)
L'ACTUEL ** [Rating: Two Stars] (212) 583-0001; 145 East 50th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues; $$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

L'Actuel is translated as ''right now,'' and the name means what it says. The restaurant is up to the minute in a very French way, but retains the essential qualities that define a brasserie. Starters include stuffed snails with garlic and butter; calamari, shrimp and heart of palm salad; white asparagus with three different hams and sauces; and duck foie gras stuffed with apricot and served with confit ginger. Entrees include seared pork filet mignon with red cabbage and calvados apples; roasted lobster with carrot spaghetti and a parsley sauce; roasted breast of chicken, vegetables tian with an herbed infusion sauce; and seared swordfish fillet with sweet corn and a green tea sauce. Desserts include lightly caramelized mango cream on mango fruit salad; melon and raspberry in a muscat wine terrine, served with a melon sorbet and a mint sauce. (Review: 2/2/00)
SONO ** [Rating: Two Stars] (212) 752-4411; 106 East 57th Street, at Lexington Avenue; $$$$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

There is a disarming simplicity to this idiosyncratic restaurant with a persuasive blend of French and Japanese cooking. Blond wood and grilled ceiling panels suggest a latter-day teahouse. First courses include crab cakes, tomato essence and shiso; grilled shrimp with yuzu zest and cayenne; stir-fried frogs' legs with garlic sprouts and bean sprouts; and lobster ravioli with lobster-seaweed bouillon. Main courses include sauteed black bass with cherry blossom and vegetable consomme; grilled pompano with white miso and stir-fried Asian vegetables; sauteed veal with edamame crust and a carrot-ginger sauce; and roasted breast of duck and leg confit, steamed buckwheat and wasabi-watercress sauce. Desserts include strawberry panna cotta; chocolate-raspberry truffle cake; and a fruit soup of lemon grass broth with passion fruit sorbet. (Review: 12/22/99)
(None) Poor to Satisfactory * Good ** Very Good *** Excellent **** Extraordinary
Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambiance and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.
Past restaurant reviews from the New York Times, with additional capsule reviews by Times critics, are available on New York Today: www.nytoday.com
